question_text:
What happens in subclavian steal syndrome?
What flow changes occur?
answer_text:
In subclavian steal syndrome, there is decreased flow and pressure distal to the stenosis or obstruction.
This results in compensatory retrograde flow from the ipsilateral vertebral artery in order to supply blood flow to the upper extremity.
This can sometimes cause basilar artery stroke like symptoms such as, dizziness, vertigo, ataxia, and double vision. These symptoms are more likely to occur with upper extremity exercise.

question_text: In subclavian steal syndrome, where is an obstruction or stenosis most commonly located within the artery?
answer_text:
In subclavian steal syndrome, an obstruction or stenosis occurs in the proximal subclavian artery, and specifically proximal to the take off of the vertebral artery.
If the occlusion is distal to the vertebral artery, a subclavian steal is not possible.

question_text: Can a subclavian steal syndrome, occur if the occlusion is distal to the vertebral artery origin?
answer_text:
No.
The occlusion must be proximal to the vertebral artery for a subclavian steal syndrome to occur.

question_text: Which side or laterality, is subclavian steal most likely to occur on?
answer_text: Subclavian steal occurs more often on the left, compared to the right.

question_text: What is the typical treatment of subclavian steal syndrome?
answer_text: Angioplasty, and stent placement.

question_text: What are the typical symptoms of posterior fossa-tumor?
answer_text: Headache, nausea, and ataxia.

question_text:
What is the most common, posterior fossa brain tumor in adults overall?
And, what is the most common, primary posterior fossa tumor in adults?
answer_text:
The most common posterior fossa tumor overall in adults, are mets.
And the most common posterior fossa primary brain tumor in adults are hemangioblastomas, which typically occur in the cerebellum.

question_text:
This is an MR brain of a 45 year old male with persistent nausea and vomiting.
What is this lesion?
What else could be considered in the differential?
answer_text:
Axial T2WI shows a posterior fossa cystic lesion, with post-contrast images demonstrating an enhancing mural nodule.
This lesion is compatible with a hemangioblastoma.
Other differentials include mets, particularly melanoma, renal cell carcinoma, and thyroid carcinoma.
If central diffusion restriction was present, an abscess could be considered.
If this patient were younger, a pilocytic astrocytoma could also be considered.

question_text:
What are the top three most common, posterior fossa brain tumors, in children,
where are they typically located, and what are their imaging features?
answer_text:
The most common posterior fossa brain tumors in children are medulloblastomas, which are malignant.
Medulloblastomas tend to occur at the midline cerebellar vermis, and are hypercellular lesions, which will cause diffusion restriction.
Because medulloblastomas are midline, they can often obstruct CSF flow in the region of the 4th ventricle, and cause hydrocephalus.
The next most common posterior fossa brain tumor in children, are pilocytic astrocytomas.
Pilocytic astrocytomas, are typically located in a single cerebellar hemisphere, and are often cystic with an enhancing mural nodule.
Ependymomas, are the third most common posterior fossa brain tumor in children.
Ependymomas arise within the 4th ventricle, and can also cause hydrocephalus.

question_text: Can you name a less common posterior fossa brain tumor in children, that typically involves the brainstem?
answer_text:
Brainstem gliomas are less common posterior fossa brain tumors in children compared to medulloblastomas, pilocytic astrocytomas, and ependymomas.
Brainstem gliomas typically involve the pons and will cause enlargement without a discrete mass.

question_text: Where are hemangioblastomas typically located in the posterior fossa?
answer_text:
Hemangioblastomas are most often seen in the cerebellum, up to 80% of the time.
Although rare, they can occasionally be seen in the brainstem.

question_text:
Okay?-get ready!
This next one will be a long and detailed answer.
What are the typical MR features of a hemangioblastoma?
What differentials must be considered?
answer_text:
Hemangioblastomas typically appear either as a cyst with a mural nodule or as a completely solid enhancing mass.
They often have vascular flow voids within or at the periphery of the lesion.
Hemangioblastomas do not demonstrate diffusion restriction.
The imaging features of a cyst with a mural nodule is the typical appearance, and occur in about 60% of cases.
A solid-enhancing mass is the other variant and occurs around 40% of the time.
The differentials of these masses depend on the overall appearance.
If the posterior fossa mass is cystic with a mural nodule, then a pilocytic astrocytoma can be considered.
However, pilocytic astrocytomas are more commonly seen in children and young adults.
The nodule enhancement is less intense and more heterogeneous in pilocytic astrocytomas, compared to hemangioblastomas.
Metastatic lesions can also be considered if there is a cyst and a mural nodule in the posterior fossa of an adult.
The metastatic lesions that typically have this appearance are melanoma and renal cell carcinoma.
The apparent cyst is often due to necrosis, rather than a true cyst.
An abscess could also be cystic in the posterior fossa.
However, an abscess will show diffusion restriction due to the debris within it.
This is a key feature, because hemangioblastomas do not restrict diffusion.
Gangliogliomas can sometimes appear cystic with a mural nodule. However, these are typically supratentorial.
These are all the differentials of a posterior fossa cyst with a mural nodule.
Now we will discuss the differential diagnoses of a solid enhancing posterior fossa mass, including: hemangioblastomas, meningiomas, metastatic lesions, and paragangliomas.
A meningioma is an extra-axial enhancing mass with a characteristic dural tail and is often found in the region of the cerebellopontine angle.
Metastatic lesions are the most common brain lesions in the posterior fossa of an adult.
In cases where there's a single solid enhancing mass, it may be challenging to differentiate between a hemangioblastoma and a solitary hypervascular metastatic lesion.
The typical hypervascular metastatic lesions are renal cell carcinomas, thyroid cancers, and melanomas.
Paragangliomas can also appear as a solid enhancing mass in the posterior fossa, but are typically in the region of the jugular foramen, and will have a heterogeneous salt-and-pepper appearance.

question_text: What age range do intracranial hemangioblastomas, most commonly occur?
answer_text: Brain hemangioblastomas are typically seen in patients between 30 and 60 years of age.

question_text: What congenital disease is associated with brain and spinal cord hemangioblastomas?
answer_text: Von Hippel-Lindau disease

question_text: If you see a brain hemangioblastoma, not, in the posterior fossa, what underlying disease, might the patient have?
answer_text: Von Hippel-Lindau disease

question_text: Patients with Von Hippel-Lindau disease more commonly develop what-kind-of brain and spinal cord tumors?
answer_text: Patients with Von Hippel-Lindau disease, more commonly develop Hemangioblastomas, and they can sometimes appear supratentorial, and even occur around the optic nerves.

question_text:
This is an MR brain of a 66 year old male with headaches and ataxia?
What is this lesion?
answer_text:
There is a mass in the left cerebellum, with T2 hyperintensity and rim enhancement, which also demonstrates abnormal diffusion restriction, confirmed on ADC (not shown in these images).
This is concerning for a posterior fossa abscess.
Also, notice the dilated occipital horns on the coronal view, suggesting obstructive hydrocephalus.

question_text: What brain lesions, are associated with tuberous sclerosis?
answer_text: Subcortical tubers, subependymal nodules, and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas.

question_text: What two brain lesions, are associated with neurofibromatosis type 1?
answer_text: Neurofibromas, and optic nerve gliomas.

question_text: What three brain lesions, are associated with neurofibromatosis type 2?
answer_text: Meningiomas, ependymomas, and schwannomas.

question_text: Is gadolinium-typically chelated?
answer_text: Yes, gadolinium is chelated. Free, non-chelated gadolinium, is very toxic.

question_text: Is typical intravenous iodinated contrast, ionic, or non-ionic? What are some examples, of ionic iodinated contrast used today?
answer_text:
Ionic iodinated contrast is old, and rarely used today.
Ionic contrast is composed of iodine ions, and was associated with increased hypersensitivity reactions, higher nephro-toxicity, more irritation to the veins, and unable to be used intrathecally.
Non-ionic iodinated contrast on-the-other-hand, is typically used today.
It is covalently bound, and does not dissociate, making it much more stable, and less likely to cause hypersensitivity reactions.
The older ionic iodinated contrast, is much more radiodense compared to the newer, non-ionic iodinated contrast we use today.
Ionic iodinated contrast can still be found today as Gastrografin and Conray, and is almost exclusively used for oral or rectal studies.

question_text: What is the difference between high-osmolar, low-osmolar, and iso-osmolar contrast medias?
answer_text:
High-osmolality contrast media agents includes older ionic iodinated contrast agents, such as Gastrografin, Conray, and Isopaque.
Most common IV contrast agents, are low-osmolality contrast media agents, such as Omnipaque.
The osmolality, of low-osmolality contrast media agents is, 600, to 900 milliosmoles per kilogram.
This is higher than human blood osmolality, but much lower than the high osmolality contrast media agents, where the osmolality is between, 1500, and 2000 milliosmoles per kilogram.
Iso-osmolar contrast media agents are also non-ionic, and the same iso-osmolarity as blood plasma around, 290 milliosmoles per kilogram.
An example of an iso-osmolar contrast agent is, visipaque.

question_text: In stroke, what does the term, benign oligemia mean?
answer_text: Benign oligemia, is a term used to describe brain tissue ischemia effects that will likely recover regardless of treatment.

question_text: What is, the ischemic penumbra?
answer_text: The penumbra, is the area with abnormal perfusion characteristics, but no restricted diffusion, and is at risk for infarct, but not infarcted at the time of imaging, and represents salvageable brain tissue.

question_text: What MRI sequence, can detect increased deoxyhemoglobin, in a vessel lumen?
answer_text: Susceptibility-weighted imaging sequences, can detect increased deoxyhemoglobin in a vessel lumen.

question_text: What type of acute hemorrhage, is not detected on SWI? What type of hemoglobin, is not detected with susceptibility-weighted imaging?
answer_text:
In cases of hyper-acute hemorrhage, the hemoglobin is still oxygenated as oxy-hemoglobin, which has no unpaired electrons, and is diamagnetic, and therefore does not create enough local magnetic field distortion to be detected with susceptibility-weighted imaging.
SWI detects paramagnetic distortions like deoxyhemoglobin, met-hemoglobin, hemosiderin, ferritin, and calcium. Hemosiderin and ferritin have the strongest susceptibility distortion on SWI.
Calcium is diamagnetic and causes less susceptibility distortions compared to iron.

question_text: In stroke perfusion imaging, what does TTP, time to peak, indicate?
answer_text:
TTP, is the time it takes for the contrast to reach its maximum enhancement, at a particular voxel.
An elevated TTP, indicates delayed arrival of blood, this is typically due to flow limiting stenosis, obstruction, or collateral circulation.

question_text: If a stroke perfusion CT, demonstrates a focal area of elevated TTP, is that finding specific to only ischemic strokes?
answer_text:
TTP, is sensitive in detecting ischemic strokes, but many other things can cause elevated TTP as well.
So, TTP is, not specific for ischemic strokes.

question_text: In stroke perfusion imaging, what does CBV, cerebral blood volume, indicate?
answer_text:
CBV indicates the total volume of blood within a given brain tissue region, defined as milliliters of blood, per 100 grams of brain.
This value gives an idea of how much residual blood is within the microvasculature. If there is normal, or elevated CBV, in a region of elevated TTP, this indicates that the collateral blood volume is maintained, which is called the ischemic penumbra.
If the CBV is low in a region of elevated TTP, this indicates there is not enough collateral flow to perfuse that region of brain, and there is a core infarct.

question_text: In stroke perfusion imaging, what does CBF, cerebral blood flow, indicate?
answer_text:
CBF, is the rate at which blood flows through the brain tissue measured as milliliters per 100 grams of brain per minute.
This value indicates the actual perfusion efficiency.
Regions of low CBF, and normal CBV, indicates an ischemic penumbra.
While a region of low CBF, and low CBV, indicates a core infarct.

question_text: In stroke perfusion imaging, what does MTT, mean transit time, indicate?
answer_text:
MTT, indicates how long blood takes to pass through a given region of brain.
It is calculated by, CBV, divided by CBF.
Regions of elevated MTT can indicate areas of delayed blood flow, and possible salvageable brain tissue in the ischemic penumbra.
MTT will be normal, or shorter in areas of a core infarct.

question_text: In stroke perfusion imaging, if the mean transit time is prolonged, and the cerebral brain volume is normal, what does this indicate about the underlying brain tissue?
answer_text: Prolonged MTT, and normal CBV, indicates ischemic penumbra, which may be salvageable.

question_text: In stroke perfusion imaging, if the mean transit time is prolonged, and the cerebral brain volume is low, what does this indicate about the underlying brain tissue?
answer_text: Prolonged MTT, and a corresponding low CBV, indicates a core infarct.

question_text: In stroke perfusion imaging, if the mean transit time is relatively normal, but the CBF is low, what does this indicate about the underlying brain tissue?
answer_text: Relatively normal MTT, and low CBF, can indicate chronic disease, or water-shed areas with lower perfusion pressures.

question_text:
A child with choanal atresia, may have other associated congenital anomalies.
What is the name for this constellation of abnormalities?
answer_text:
Charge Syndrome.
Which consist of: Coloboma, Heart disease, Choanal Atresia, retardation, genital abnormalities, and ear anomalies.

question_text: What vomer width measurement, on CT imaging in a child, is considered suggestive of choanal atresia?
answer_text: 6 millimeters or less in width.

question_text: What are the common presenting symptoms of an infant with subependymal heterotopia?
answer_text: Seizures, and developmental delay.

question_text: How do subependymal tubers, differ from subependymal heterotopia?
answer_text:
Subependymal tubers are glial hamartomas, seen in tuberous sclerosis, typically lining the ventricles and often with calcifications.
Subependymal heterotopia are displaced normal neurons, that form ectopic gray-matter nodules along the ventricular walls, representing a neuronal-migration disorder, rather than a hamartoma.

question_text:
Which of these brain lesions typically calcify?
Subependymal tubers, or subependymal heterotopia?
answer_text: Subependymal tubers, almost always calcify (up to 98%), while subependymal heterotopia, are not associated with calcifications.

question_text: Why are cases of subependymal heterotopia more common in females?
answer_text:
Subependymal heterotopia, is often caused by a mutation in the FLNA gene on the X chromosome, which is critical for actin cytoskeleton stability and neuronal migration.
Because the disorder is X-linked, males who inherit the mutation typically do not have a normal, second X chromosome to compensate, leading to non-viability in-utero.
As a result, surviving cases overwhelmingly occur in females (over 90% of cases).

question_text: What other anatomical abnormality is commonly associated with subependymal heterotopia?
answer_text: Polymicrogyria, is the most common associated abnormality with subependymal heterotopia.

question_text: How are peri-ventricular nodular heterotopia, PNH, different from subependymal heterotopia?
answer_text:
They refer to the same entity.
Peri-ventricular nodular heterotopia, PNH, is the formal term for subependymal heterotopia, describing ectopic gray-matter nodules lining the ventricular walls due to failed neuronal migration.

question_text: In craniopharyngiomas, what are the typical bi-modal distribution age peaks?
answer_text: Craniopharyngiomas, most commonly occur in children from 5 to 14 years, and in adults from 50 to 75 years of age.

question_text: What is the peak age range, for pituitary macroadenomas?
answer_text:
Pituitary macroadenomas most often occur in adults, with the peak incidence between 30 and 60 years of age.
Macroadenomas are uncommon in children.

question_text: What MRI characteristics help differentiate craniopharyngiomas from pituitary macroadenomas?
answer_text:
Craniopharyngiomas are suprasellar in origin, and are typically mixed cystic and solid lesions, with heterogeneous enhancement.
They contain calcifications in up to 90% of cases.
Pituitary macroadenomas on-the-other-hand, arise from the sella and extend superiorly as they enlarge.
They are generally solid and demonstrate homogeneous enhancement.
Macroadenomas rarely contain calcifications.

question_text:
What are the MRI features, of primary CNS lymphoma?
Describe the typical location, T2 signal, enhancement, and diffusion restriction.
answer_text:
Primary CNS lymphoma typically occurs in deep periventricular regions of the brain, and is classically iso-intense or mildly hypo-intense on T1 and T2-weighted imaging with surrounding vasogenic edema.
A hallmark feature is its avid, homogenous enhancement, accompanied by marked diffusion restriction.
Primary CNS lymphoma, typically does not contain internal hemorrhage or calcifications.

question_text: How do steroids affect the imaging and diagnosis, of primary CNS lymphoma?
answer_text:
Steroids can cause primary CNS lymphoma to shrink rapidly or temporarily disappear, creating a major diagnostic challenge.
Because the lesion regresses before biopsy, tissue sampling may become non-diagnostic; delaying or obscuring the correct diagnosis.

question_text:
What part of the brain should be investigated, when a patient presents with an upward gaze palsy?
What is this syndrome called?
answer_text: This is called Parinaud syndrome, where an upward gaze palsy localizes to the dorsal midbrain, particularly the tectal region and superior colliculus.

question_text:
When talking about the venous system of the brain.
What is a Falcine sinus?
answer_text:
The Falcine sinus, is a fetal remnant structure that is persistent in about 2% of adults.
The falcine sinus drains into the superior sagittal sinus, and usually arises from the vein of Galen or-straight sinus.

question_text: If a patient has a vein of Galen aneurysm, what venous anomaly is often present?
answer_text: A persistent falcine sinus is often present.

question_text: What is a common cardiac complication, that occurs in cases of vein of Galen malformation, and some brain AVMs?
answer_text: Brain AVMs and especially vein of Galen malformations often have cardiac complications with high-output congestive heart failure due to the left-to-right shunt.

question_text: Are seizures a common presentation in brain AVMs?
answer_text:
Not usually. Unless the AVM is located along the cortex.
The most common presentation of a brain AVM is intracranial hemorrhage.

question_text: What is the difference between, brain AVMs, and AVFs?
answer_text: Prolonged MTT, and normal CBV, indicates ischemic penumbra, which maybe salvageable.

question_text:
Are dural AVFs, congenital, or acquired?
What are the main causes?
answer_text: Dural AVFs are acquired. And most commonly develop secondarily to dural sinus thrombosis, trauma, prior surgery, or infection.

question_text: How is a Vein of Galen malformation treated?
answer_text: A Vein of Galen malformation is treated by neuro-interventionalist, using angiography or venography, with embolization of the shunt, utilizing glue, coils, or some other embolization material.

question_text:
Can you name three cystic odontogenic lesions?

And how about two common benign odontogenic tumors?
answer_text:
Three common cystic odontogenic lesions are: radicular cysts (also called periapical cysts), dentigerous cysts, and odontogenic keratocysts.
Two common benign odontogenic tumors are odontomas, and ameloblastomas.

question_text: What is this odontogenic lesion?
answer_text: There is a mildly expansile unilocular lytic-lesion in the right mandibular angle with imaging characteristics of an odontogenic keratocyst, or possibly an ameloblastoma.

question_text:
Are odontogenic keratocysts, benign, or malignant?
Where do they most commonly occur?
answer_text:
Odontogenic keratocysts (previously called, keratocystic odontogenic tumors) are benign bone lesions, which have been recently classified as cystic lesions.
They overwhelmingly occur in the posterior mandible, they can also sometimes occur in the maxilla.

question_text: What is the typical age range of odontogenic keratocysts? And what are common presenting symptoms?
answer_text:
Odontogenic keratocysts typically occur in patients between the ages of 20 and 40 years old.
These lesions are commonly discovered incidentally.
However, if they are symptomatic, there will often be jaw pain, and possible swelling.

question_text: Should odontogenic keratocyst be surgically removed?
answer_text:
Yes. Odontogenic keratocysts require surgical treatment because of their locally aggressive behavior.
These lesions can have a high rate of recurrence after removal.

question_text: Should an odontogenic keratocyst (OKC), be followed with imaging after surgery?
answer_text:
Yes, Long-term follow-up is mandatory because recurrence rates are high.
Imaging with panoramic dental x-ray or a CT is typically obtained at 6 to 12 months after surgery, and then annually for several years.

question_text: What congenital syndrome is classically associated with odontogenic keratocysts?
answer_text: Gorlin syndrome (also called Nevoid Basal Cell Carcinoma Syndrome) is the congenital syndrome classically associated with odontogenic keratocysts.

question_text: Can you think of five lesions or imaging-features that are associated with Gorlin Syndrome?
answer_text: Multiple odontogenic keratocysts of the jaw, numerous basal cell carcinomas, medulloblastomas, falx-cerebri calcifications, and skeletal anomalies (like bifid ribs, and scoliosis).

question_text: What is this lesion?
answer_text:
Dentigerous cyst

The CT axial images show a well circumscribed cystic space around the "crown" of an unerupted third molar, extending to the cementoenamel junction.
This is the characteristic appearance of a dentigerous cyst.

question_text: How to potentially differentiate between a periapical granuloma and a radicular cyst?
answer_text: Both periapical granulomas and radicular cysts appear as periapical lucencies. In general, a periapical granuloma is less corticated and smaller in size (less than 1 centimeter), compared to radicular cysts, which are well corticated and often larger in size (greater than 1 centimeter). Periapical granulomas can be symptomatic and painful, whereas radicular cysts are often asymptomatic.

question_text: What is a dentigerous cyst?
answer_text:
A dentigerous cyst is a cystic lesion that develops around the crown of an unerupted or impacted tooth, most commonly a mandibular third molar.
In these cases, the tooth typically has a fully formed crown but incompletely developed roots.

question_text: What imaging features can help differentiate an odontogenic keratocyst, from a dentigerous cyst.
answer_text:
A dentigerous cyst always envelops the crown of an impacted tooth, and attachment is at the cementoenamel junction.
Dentigerous cyst have more outward buccolingual expansion.
Odontogenic keratocyst may be near an impacted tooth, but do not arise from the cementoenamel junction, and expansion is usually minimal.
Growth is typically antero-posterior, or parallel, along the axis of the bone, rather than outward.

question_text: What is this lesion?
question_source_name: Salvatore V. Labruzzo; Laurie A. Loevner; Efrat Saraf-Lavi; David M. Yousem
answer_text: CT axial imaging with a soft tissue and bone kernel demonstrates a well-circumscribed lesion within the right mandible, oriented in the long axis, and not associated with a carious tooth. This is likely an odontogenic keratocyst (formerly known as a keratocystic odontogenic tumor). A unicameral bone cyst could also be considered.

question_text: What is this lesion?
answer_text: This multi-planar reconstruction CT, demonstrates an expansile, well-circumscribed lesion, with internal septations, suggestive of an "ameloblastoma".

question_text: What is an ameloblastoma?
answer_text: Ameloblastomas are locally-aggressive benign tumors that often arise from the mandible.

question_text:
Ameloblastomas often appear cystic and multi-locular on imaging.
Why then are they not considered a cystic odontogenic lesion?
answer_text:
Ameloblastomas fall under the category of benign odontogenic tumors.
It is a solid neoplasm that undergoes cystic degeneration, producing its characteristic multi-loculated cyst-like appearance. 
Often mimicking true cysts like odontogenic keratocysts, or dentigerous cysts.

question_text: What imaging features can help differentiate between an odontogenic keratocyst and an ameloblastoma?
answer_text: Ameloblastomas can appear more loculated, with a “soap-bubble” appearance, and will have much more cortical expansion and thinning compared to OKCs.

question_text: What imaging features can help differentiate an odontogenic keratocyst, from a simple unicameral bone cyst in the mandible?
answer_text:
Both lesions can have endosteal scalloping. However, a simple bone cyst can have scalloping that occurs between the roots and does not displace the teeth or cause expansion.
Compared to odontogenic keratocysts, which also have scalloping but does not occur between the roots, and can be expansile displacing teeth.

question_text: What is this lesion?
answer_text: MR images show a cystic lesion along the anterior hard palate of the maxilla with rim enhancement consistent with a nasopalatine duct cyst.

question_text: What is this lesion?
answer_text:
This is a stafne bone defect.

CT axial and coronal views of the mandible show well-circumscribed remodeling of the medial cortex of the mandible with a small portion of the submandibular gland extending into the defect.
This is a benign finding called a, Stafne bone defect.

question_text: What is a Stafne bone defect?
answer_text:
A Stafne bone defect is a cortical defect in the posterior mandible below the mandibular canal, representing a depression in the medial aspect of the mandible filled by part of the submandibular gland, or adjacent fat.
It occurs due to remodeling, caused by adjacent soft tissues, most commonly the submandibular gland.

question_text: What is this lesion?
answer_text:
CT axial views show a well circumscribed lesion in the right maxilla, containing heterogeneous densities, and several discernable tooth like elements.
The adjacent teeth roots are being splayed.
This is an example of an odontoma, and because there are visible tooth elements, such as enamel and cementum within the lesion, this is a "compound" odontoma.

question_text: What is an odontoma?
answer_text:
An odontoma, is essentially a hamartoma of tooth-forming tissues.
Odontomas specifically form tooth tissue; not bone.

question_text: What are the two main categories that odontomas can be classified into based on their appearance?
answer_text:
"Compound" odontomas, which contain identifiable tooth components.
And "complex" odontomas, which contain irregular calcified lesions with no distinct tooth components.

question_text:
What is the typical definitive management of a dentigerous cyst?
And what about ameloblastomas and odontomas?
answer_text: Dentigerous cysts, ameloblastomas, and odontomas, all require surgical resection.

question_text:
CT imaging of a 20-year-old male.
What is this incidental finding?
answer_text: There is a non-enhancing cystic lesion in the anterior midline hard palate consistent with a nasopalatine duct cyst.

question_text:
What is this?
What are the top differential causes?
question_source_name: Salvatore V. Labruzzo; Laurie A. Loevner; Efrat Saraf-Lavi; David M. Yousem
answer_text:
This is a compression deformity called "vertebra plana."
The posterior elements and disc space are usually intact, which differentiates this from a traumatic or degenerative etiology.
The top differentials include Langerhans cell histiocytosis (also called eosinophilic granuloma), leukemia and lymphoma, infection, and metastatic disease.

question_text: Most common cause of vertebra plana in children less than 16 years old?
answer_text: In children, the most common cause of vertebra plana is Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

question_text:
What is the most common osseous site for Langerhans cell histiocytosis?
What other locations can be involved?
answer_text: Langerhans cell histiocytosis most commonly involves the skull, and the parietal bone is the most frequent bone involved, followed by the frontal and occipital bones. Other sites outside of the skull include the mandible, vertebrae, ribs, and pelvis.

question_text: Which spinal level is most commonly involved in vertebral Langerhans cell histiocytosis?
answer_text: The thoracic vertebrae are most frequently involved in cases of langerhans cell histiocytosis.

question_text:
This lateral radiograph of the thoracic spine shows vertebra plana caused by Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
What is the typical management of these cases?
answer_text:
Conservative management.
Vertebroplasty is not effective in these cases.

question_text: How do Langerhans cell histiocytosis skull lesions appear on a nuclear medicine bone scan?
answer_text:
A Technetium-99 MDP (Methylene Diphosphonate) scan can show focal areas of radiotracer uptake.
However, in the skull, there are often focal areas of decreased uptake.

question_text: What is the most common cause of multiple lytic lesions without a sclerotic rim in the skull of a child?
answer_text: Langerhans cell histiocytosis

question_text: What are these bone lesions?
answer_text: Numerous benign enostoses. This is osteopoikilosis.

question_text: What other brain imaging findings are associated with cavernous malformations?
answer_text: Developmental venous anomalies

question_text: Are cavernous malformations, always formed from a previous developmental venous anomaly?
answer_text:
No not always.
But, the chronic venous hypertension within a DVA can result in a cavernous malformation sometimes.

question_text:
How are sequences for gradient echo imaging (GRE) and T2WI different?
How does GRE cause increased sensitivity to magnetic susceptibility compared to conventional T2WI?
answer_text:
A typical T2 sequence contains a 90-degree excitation pulse, followed by a 180-degree refocusing pulse.
Where a "GRE sequence" only contains the 90-degree excitation pulse and no refocusing pulse.
Let me explain in more detail.
Elemental materials such as iron and calcium, along with air-to-bone interfaces, cause small local magnetic changes which cause varying precession rates of nearby tissues.
Any varying precession-rate from the uniform precession frequency, determined by B-0 causes a loss of signal.
Which is precisely what you want when looking for blood with a GRE sequence.
A T2 sequence will add a 180-degree refocusing pulse, essentially flipping the precession rates, so a precession rate that was previously slower is now faster, and a precession rate that was previously faster is now slower, effectively evening out the precession rate and eliminating signal loss, making a beautiful T2-weighted image.
In summary, a T2 sequence contains the 90-degree excitation pulse followed by a 180-refocusing pulse, which corrects for the local magnetic field inhomogeneities caused by iron, calcium and air.
Where a GRE sequence contains the 90-degree excitation pulse, without a refocusing pulse allowing the local magnetic field inhomogeneities to remain as low signal indicating regions of possible blood.

question_text: Which is more sensitive in detecting susceptibility artifacts, SWI or T2-star GRE?
answer_text:
SWI is almost 4 times more sensitive than T2-star GRE.

question_text: What are the top three most common 4th ventricle masses in children?
answer_text:
In children, the top three most common masses involving the 4th ventricle are ependymomas, medulloblastomas, and choroid plexus papillomas. 
Ependymomas are the most common true intraventricular mass, often containing calcifications, and are often heterogeneous with cysts or elements of hemorrhage.
Choroid Plexus Papillomas have frond, or feathery-leaf-like enhancement, and can cause hydrocephalus due to excess CSF production.
They are more often found in the lateral ventricles of young children and in the 4th ventricle of older children.
Medulloblastomas do not actually arise from the 4th ventricle, but instead arise from the cerebellar vermis and will grow into the 4th ventricle. 
Medulloblastomas are homogeneous in appearance and are highly cellular, meaning there will be abnormal diffusion restriction.

Later at 6 to 12 months, amorphous calcifications will begin to form within the lymph node and will continue calcify over the next few years.

question_text:
In thyroid-eye-disease, the extraocular rectus muscles become inflamed and thickened in a predictable pattern.
What is the typical order of extraocular muscle involvement?
answer_text: With thyroid eye disease, use the mnemonic, "I'm, slow." Inferior, medial, superior, lateral, and oblique rectus muscles.

question_text:
Are the tendinous insertions of the extraocular muscles typically involved in thyroid eye disease?
What diseases typically involves the tendinous insertions of the extraocular muscles?
answer_text:
Thyroid eye disease, characteristically spares the tendinous insertion of the extra-occular muscles.
Eye diseases that often involve the tendons include, orbital pseudotumor, orbital IGG-4-related disease, granulomatous orbital inflammation (as seen in sarcoidosis and granulomatosis-with-polyangiitis).

question_text: When would a patient with thyroid eye disease require surgical intervention?
answer_text:
Rarely is there a need for surgical intervention, the few instances are when there is risk of optic nerve damage.
In these cases, a medial orbital wall decompression is performed.
Where the bones of the orbital wall are removed, usually the medial and/or inferior orbital walls which creates more space and reduces tension on the optic nerve. 
In some cases the proptosis is so pronounced the eyelids cannot fully close leading to exposure keratitis and a similar procedure can be performed.

question_text:
What happens in thyroid eye disease?
Are cases of thyroid eye disease more common in hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism?
answer_text:
Thyroid eye disease more commonly occurs in cases of hyperthyroidism.
Up to 90% of cases of thyroid eye disease occur in patients with hyperthyroidism Grave's disease.
In Grave's disease, the immune system mistakenly produces thyrotropin receptor antibodies which mimic thyroid stimulating hormone causing hyperthyroidism.
These same thyrotropin receptor antibodies also inflame the extra-occular muscles.
This is because the fibroblasts which reside in between the extra-occular muscle fibers also contain TSH receptors.
The fibroblast then undergo adipogenesis and turn into fat cells and produce a large amount of glycosaminoglycans increasing the extra-occluar muscle size and edema.
Thyroid eye disease can sometimes be caused in cases of euthyroid where there are circulating antibodies but the T3, T4, and TSH levels are normal.
Although very rare, thyroid eye disease can sometimes be seen in cases of hypothyroidism from Hashimoto's thyroiditis due to increased stimulation of the TSH receptors of the extra-occular muscle fibroblasts.
In cases of thyroid eye disease from Hashimoto's the symptoms are often less severe and more likely to be unilateral or asymmetric.

question_text:
What is the most common cause of bilateral exophthalmos in adults?
What about unilateral exophthalmos?
answer_text:
The most common cause of both unilateral and bilateral exophthalmos in adults is thyroid eye disease.
Although thyroid eye disease can be unilateral, most cases are bilateral, up to 90% of cases.

Unilateral enlargement of the right lateral rectus muscle with involvement of the tendinous insertion.

question_text: What are the most common mimics idiopathic orbital inflammation, also called orbital pseudotumor?
answer_text:
IGG-4 related ophthalmic disease is by far the most common mimic of idiopathic orbital inflammation (accounting for up to 25  to 50% of cases).
Thyroid eye disease can sometimes have an atypical appearance and can also mimic idiopathic orbital inflammation.
Other less common mimics of idiopathic orbital inflammation to consider are granulomatosis with polyangiitis, sarcoidosis, lupus along with other rheumatologic conditions, and low-grade lymphoma.

The major concern is retinal detachment due to the extensive inflammation of the posterior orbit.

question_text: What are some key imaging features in Dandy-Walker malformation?
answer_text:
A small cerebellar vermis which is rotated upwards with cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle and expansion of the skull to accommodate the enlarged posterior fossa.
The enlargement of the posterior fossa is often described by torcular-lambdoid inversion, where the torcula is positioned above the lambdoid suture.

question_text: How often is hydrocephalus seen in cases of Dandy-Walker malformation?
answer_text: Hydrocephalus occurs often in cases of Dandy-Walker malformation, up to 75% of the time. This is more than ataxia or any other symptomatic presentation.

question_text:
At what gestational age does the cerebellar vermis begin to form?
In what orientation does it form?
answer_text: The cerebellar vermis begins to form at week 7 and develops from superior to inferior.

question_text: At what gestational age does the choroid plexus form and start making CSF?
answer_text: The choroid plexus forms and starts making CSF around weeks 8 and 9.

question_text:
At what gestational week does the superior cerebellar vermis fuse?
When does the inferior cerebellar vermis fuse?
answer_text: The superior cerebellar vermis fuses at week 9, and the inferior vermis fuses around week 15.

question_text:
When does the Foramen of Magendie form?
Where does it perforate from?
answer_text: The Foramen of Magendie perforates from the posterior membranous area of the fourth ventricle roof, by first making a Blake's pouch that initially bulges and then perforates through around weeks 12 and 13.

question_text: At what gestational week do the Foramina of Luschka form?
answer_text: The foramen of Luschka form around weeks 16 and 17.

question_text:
What are these angles called?
What ranges are considered normal, and which suggest a Dandy-Walker malformation?
answer_text:
First there is an inverted-"V" which is the tegmentovermian angle.
Tegmentum, means "covering" in Latin, and vermis, meaning "worm".
A normal tegmentovermian angle is less than 10 degrees.
If the angle is greater than 40 degrees, this raises suspicion for an abnormality such as Dandy-Walker malformation.
Next there is a wider angle along the ventral aspect of the cerebellum representing the fastigial recess angle. Normally this angle is less than 90 degrees.
However when it becomes obtuse, this can raise suspicion for a Dandy-Walker malformation also.

question_text: Which cerebellar developmental abnormality underlies a Dandy Walker malformation?
answer_text:
In a Dandy-Walker malformation the cerebellum is underdeveloped and the inferior cerebellar vermis fails to fuse.
This causes a large dilated communication between the fourth ventricle and the subarachnoid space.

question_text:
What causes a Blake's pouch cyst to form?
How is this mechanism different from Dandy-Walker malformation?
answer_text:
A Blake’s pouch cyst forms from failure or delayed fenestration of the foramen of Magendie, causing a enlarging Blake’s pouch which becomes cystic.
The cerebellum is otherwise normally formed and the posterior fossa is not abnormally expanded.
In Dandy–Walker malformation, the primary defect is abnormal development of the cerebellar vermis, leading to an enlarged fourth ventricle and an expanded posterior fossa.
Both of these entities can result in hydrocephalus.
answer_image_source: Volpe's Neurology of the Newborn (Seventh Edition) - 2025, Pages 89-121

question_text: What is wrong with the cerebellum here?

This can be seen in Dandy Walker malformation or in cases of isolated inferior vermian hypoplasia. 
For this to be Dandy-Walker there would also need to be cystic dilation of the 4th ventricle, upward rotation of the cerebellum and enlargement of the posterior fossa.

question_text: What is the arbitrary measurement used to determine when cerebellar tonsil extension below the foramen magnum is suggestive of a Chiari Type 1 abnormality.
answer_text:
Greater than 5 mm is compatible with a Chiari type 1 abnormality.
However, inferior displacement of the cerebellar tonsils at 6 and 7 mm is not always pathologic.
If there's no CSF effacement, syringomyelia, or clinical symptoms, it may be physiologic cerebellar tonsillar ectopia.

question_text: In a Chiari abnormality what does the presences of syringomyelia indicate?
answer_text:
In a Chiari malformation, the presence of syringomyelia indicates obstruction of CSF flow at the foramen magnum.
It indicates there is a pressure dissociation between intracranial and spinal subarachnoid spaces driving fluid into the spinal cord parenchyma.
When this occurs, conservative management is typically not helpful, and a suboccipital decompression is required.

question_text: What abnormality of the C2 dens process can be associated with a chiari type 1 malformation?
answer_text: A Retroverted dens

question_text: By what mechanism can Crouzon syndrome contribute to a Chiari malformation? What are other features seen with Crouzon syndrome?
answer_text:
Crouzon syndrome (also called craniofacial dysostosis) is a congenital disease where there is an autosomal dominant mutation of the fibroblast-growth-factor-receptor-2.
This mutation causes extensive premature suture closures of the calvarium and particularly of the coronal sutures.
Essentially the small skull forces the brain to protrude inferiorly.
Additional Crouzon syndrome features include brachycephaly (where the skull is short from front to back), hypertelorism (increased distance between the eyes), orbital proptosis, and bifid uvula.
The hands and feet are normal, which differentiates this disease from other synostoses.

question_text: How can the position of the taenia-tela choroidea complexes be used to differentiate a Dandy-Walker malformation from a Blake pouch cyst?
answer_text:
In Dandy-Walker malformation, the taenia–tela choroidea complex are displaced downward and laterally, reflecting vermian agenesis and there is an enlarged posterior fossa.
In a Blake pouch cyst, the taenia–tela choroidea complex remains in a normal or near-normal position, because the cerebellar vermis and posterior fossa are normally developed.
answer_image_source: Figure 4.20 from Chapter 4 of Volpe's Neurology of the Newborn (Seventh Edition) - 2025, Pages 89-121

question_text: What is the typical initial surgical management of syringomyelia in cases of a chiari type 1 malformation? If the syringomyelia continues, what other surgical procedure can be performed?
answer_text:
In cases of syringomyelia due to a chiari malformation conservative management is typically not helpful and a suboccipital decompression is required.
If the suboccipital decompression isn't enough in opening up the space of the foramen magnum, a duraplasty is the next option to increase the space for CSF to flow.

question_text: What is the exact mechanism behind a syrinx formation in Chiari malformation?
answer_text:
The pressure within the thecal sac and the cranium are near equal, even when there is obstruction of bidirectional CSF flow at the foramen magnum.
The issue becomes with each heartbeat there is a slight relative increase in pressure of the subarachnoid CSF surrounding the spinal cord.
This relative increase in pressure, slowly drives fluid within the spinal cord, forming the syrinx.

question_text: What are the four types of holoprosencephaly?
answer_text:
Holoprosencephaly is classically divided into alobar (which is the most severe type), semilobar, lobar, and middle interhemispheric variant (also called syntelencephaly).
Alobar holoprosencephaly is characterized by complete failure of hemispheric separation, resulting in a single mono-ventricle, an absent falx, fused thalami, and severe midline facial anomalies, most commonly hypo-telorism.
Semilobar holoprosencephaly demonstrates partial posterior hemispheric separation with persistent anterior, or frontal fusion, an incompletely formed falx, incomplete ventricular separation, and an absent or severely hypoplastic corpus callosum.
Lobar holoprosencephaly shows near-complete hemispheric separation with a present but often anteriorly hypoplastic falx, variable callosal abnormalities (commonly partial agenesis), and relatively well-formed lateral ventricles.
The middle interhemispheric variant is defined by failed separation of the posterior frontal and parietal lobes, with preserved separation of the forebrain and occipital lobes.

question_text: If a new chiari type 1 malformation is discovered should an MR of the cervical spine, or the entire spine be performed next?

The entire spine should be evaluated, not just the cervical spine.
Syringomyelia can still occur in the thoracic or lumbar spine, although less commonly compared to the cervical spine.
Also a tethered cord or spinal dysraphism must be evaluated.

question_text: In tuberous sclerosis, "where" are subependymal giant cell astrocytomas most likely to be located?

What skin lesions are associated with tuberous sclerosis?

facial angiofibromas and ash-leaf spots are associated with tuberous sclerosis.
In the kidneys, angiomyolipomas, in the lungs lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM), and in the heart, rhabdomyomas.

Multiple small, irregular gyri with thickened cortex and indistinct gray-white junction seen in this case are characteristic of pachygyria polymicrogyria.

question_text: What does the term "acquired" Chiari type 1 malformation mean?

question_text: What are benign intracranial lipomas associated with?

question_text:
What is transverse myelitis?
What is the goal of MRI in cases of suspected transverse myelitis?
answer_text:
Transverse myelitis is a clinical syndrome of acute to subacute spinal cord dysfunction causing bilateral neurologic deficits that may involve the motor, sensory, and/or autonomic pathways, often with a definable sensory level.
The cause maybe idiopathic, or secondary to a demyelinating, autoimmune, granulomatous, paraneoplastic, or post-infectious processes.
MRI is expected to show cord signal abnormality and is essential to exclude compressive, vascular, or alternative causes, and to support an inflammatory etiology.
In some cases, an early MRI may appear normal in the first 24 hours.
In these cases CSF inflammatory markers may support the diagnosis if the initial MR is negative.

question_text: What type of neurologic symptoms would not be consistent with transverse myelitis?
answer_text:
Symptoms that are not consistent with transverse myelitis include: sensory or motor deficits that are purely unilateral and do not involve the contralateral side, stocking–glove type sensory loss, cases of areflexia without upper motor neuron signs, and fluctuating or fatigable weakness (as seen in myasthenia gravis).
Transverse myelitis also includes a clear timeframe.
If the symptoms have resolved within 4 hours or have persisted for over 21 days, then these are favored to be from other etiologies.
Acute transverse myelitis must include neurologic deficits which are bilateral, but do not have to be symmetric, and typically have a defined sensory level.
Urinary urgency, inability to void, or bowel or bladder incontinence are included as possible symptoms of transverse myelitis.

question_text: What type of cancers are most commonly associated with transverse myelitis secondary to a paraneoplastic process?
answer_text: Breast and small cell lung cancers.

question_text: Should transverse myelitis lesions be biopsied?
answer_text: No! Transverse myelitis lesions do not require biopsy.

question_text: MR findings of transverse myelitis are non-specific but contain what general features?
answer_text:
Spinal cord lesions typically have ill-defined margins and extend longitudinally for 3 to 4 vertebral segments and include more than two thirds of the spinal cord cross-sectional area.
Enhancement is variable, and is sometimes absent.

question_text:
A patient presents to the ED and is having acute to subacute bilateral neurologic deficits localizing to a spinal cord level.
Before the MRI is performed what is the correct term to describe this patients syndromic condition?
When is the term acute transverse myelitis used?
answer_text:
The patient is presenting with acute to subacute bilateral neurologic deficits localizing to a specific spinal cord level.
Before an MRI is performed, these symptoms are classified as acute myelopathy.
Once an MRI is performed to exclude compression, tumor, hemorrhage, or a vascular cause and there is intramedullary spinal cord inflammatory signal, then the term "acute transverse myelitis" can be used.
Acute transverse myelitis (ATM) describes a clinical syndrome and is not the final diagnosis.
If the spinal cord lesions are specific for MS, then the term MS-associated myelitis is used and the term ATM is dropped.
If the initial MRI raises concern for ATM then a secondary cause is explored (such as neuromyelitis optica, MOGAD, sarcoid, paraneoplastic, autoimmune, or post-infectious) before a final diagnosis of idiopathic ATM is made.

question_text: A patient presents with symptoms of bilateral, asymmetric, neurologic deficits localizing to a spinal cord level. An initial MRI is performed. What features are used to differentiate acute transverse myelitis from multiple sclerosis lesions?
answer_text: When trying to distinguish between ATM and the spinal cord lesions of MS, evaluation of the longitudinal and cross-sectional extent of the lesion is crucial. In most cases, the spinal cord lesions of MS are smaller with shorter longitudinal segments involving one or two vertebral segments and are more peripherally located in the cord. While, ATM lesions occupy more than two thirds of the cord cross-sectional area and extend three or more vertebral segments longitudinally.

question_text: In MR spine imaging are ATM lesions or tumors typically associated with syrinx formation?
answer_text: ATM lesions do not typically form syrinx, while spinal cord tumors can cause a syrinx.

question_text: In MR spine imaging, how can diffuse tensor imaging help in evaluating patients with suspected acute transverse myelitis?
answer_text:
T2 hyperintense spinal cord lesions have corresponding decreased fractional
anisotropy in ATM lesions and can have areas of decreased fractional anisotropy without and associated T2 hyperintensity and appear otherwise normal. Indicating there may be areas of the spinal cord can only be detected with diffuse tensor imaging.

question_text: What part of the spinal cord is most commonly affected in acute transverse myelitis?
answer_text: The thoracic cord is the most commonly affected region in ATM.

question_text: In spine imaging. How often is spinal cord expansion and focal peripheral cord enhancement seen in acute transverse myelitis?
answer_text: Spinal cord expansion and focal, peripheral cord enhancement is seen in about 50% of cases of acute transverse myelitis. These findings are less common than the T2 hyperintensity involving two thirds of the spinal cord cross-sectional area (90%) and extension over a length of three to four or more vertebral segments (60%).

question_text: In spine imaging, what is longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM)?
answer_text: Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM), is a term used in MR spine imaging where there is abnormal T2 signal traversing at least three vertebral body segments in length, this is description is non-specific but essentially excludes MS-associated myelitis.

question_text: What is the other name for Devic’s syndrome?
answer_text: Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder, which is a severe demyelinating disease that primarily involves the optic nerves and spinal cord.

question_text: In cases of Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder what is the typical gender and age of onset?
answer_text: Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder more commonly affects women, and has a peak incidence around 35 - 40 years of age.

question_text: What CSF auto-antibody is used to diagnose Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder?
answer_text: The AQP4 anti-body. Auto-antibody to the aquaporin-4.

question_text: Is this spinal lesions more compatible with MS-associated myelitis or acute transverse myelitis?
question_image_source: Imaging of the Spine: Expert Consult, Chapter 21, Figure 21-2.
answer_text: This spinal lesions demonstrates abnormal signal intensity and enhancement spanning 3 vertebral segments and the full cross-sectional area of the spinal cord. These findings are compatible with ATM and are not consistent with MS-associated myelitis which are much shorter, smaller, and often multiple.

question_text: If a patient has an MR of the spine and shows abnormal signal changes spanning 1 - 2 vertebral segments. Before considering MS-associated myelitis what clinical history must be considered?
answer_text: In cases of resolving longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis the lesions will shrink. The clinical history and onset of symptoms to when the MR is performed is crucial in distinguishing an acute transverse myelitis that is resolving from an MS-associated myelitis.

question_text:
In cases where there are optic nerve and spinal cord T2 hyperintensity lesions, does the presence or absence of subcortical white matter
lesions in the brain change the diagnosis of neuromyelitis optica and multiple sclerosis.
answer_text: Although optic nerve, spinal cord and brain white matter lesions are more common in multiple sclerosis their presences in the brain does not eliminate the possibility of neuromyelitis optica. However, if there are only optic nerve and spinal cord lesions, and no brain lesions, the likelihood of neuromyelitis optica is very high compared to multiple sclerosis.

question_text: 50 year old male with lower extremity weakness. What is this?
question_image_source: Imaging of the Spine: Expert Consult, Chapter 21
answer_text: There is diffuse enhancement of the lumbar nerve roots preferentially involving the ventral roots, which is consistent with Guillain-Barré syndrome.

question_text: Based on this single MR sagittal STIR of a 25 year old female what is the most likely demyelinating disease?
answer_text:
There are STIR signal within the cord spanning from C6 and C7 and in the upper thoracic
cord. These findings are suggestive of MS, given the short segment of involvement and multiplicity of lesions.

question_text: This patient has a history of cancer and prior radiation therapy presents with bilateral upextremity weakness and sensory loss along a C5 - C7 distribution. Based on the single sagittal T2-fat suppressed, what is the likely cause of their myelitis?
answer_text: The is MR demonstrates multiple bone metastases and prior radiation changes. There is diffuse increased signal changes in the spinal cord. The primary considerations would be radiation myelopathy or  paraneoplastic myelopathy.

question_text: What part of the spinal cord is most commonly affected in MS-associated myelitis?
answer_text: The cervical spinal cord and the dorsolateral aspects. The lesions are less than 2 vertebral segments longitudinally and less than half of the axial cross section of the cord.

question_text: In patients with active MS myelitis, how long can abnormal spinal cord lesion enhancement last?
answer_text: In MS-associated myelitis, lesional enhancement can last approximately 1 - 2 months, however this has no indication on disease progression.

question_text: This patient has bilateral asymmetric upper extremity weakness. MR shows incomplete ring enhancement at C6-C7. What is the likely process causing this patient's myelopathy?
answer_text: Open or incomplete ring enhancement is more often associated with a demyelinating process compared to complete ring enhancement which is more commonly seen in infection or tumors. This was a short small lesion and the patient was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis.

question_text: What demyelinating process is most compatible with this MR findings?
answer_text:
There are multiple short-segment foci with T2
hyperintensity and enhancement. These findings are consistent with multiple sclerosis.

question_text: Patients with neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder can sometimes develop T2 hyperintense brain lesions. Where are these brain lesions commonly located?
answer_text: The typical distribution of brain lesions in neuromyelitis optica include the periependymal regions surrounding the 3rd and 4th ventricles, cerebral aqueduct, and medulla.

question_text: Is adult or child acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM) more likely to be MOG-IG positive?
answer_text: Children are more likely to have ADEM with MOG-IG antibodies (up to 50%), compared to adults (around 10 - 20%).

question_text: What is most likely presentation of MOGAD in adults?
answer_text: Optic neuritis alone. Sometimes myelitis is also present. ADEM is rare in adults.

question_text: Is optic neuritis in MOGAD typically bilateral or unilateral?
answer_text: The optic neuritis in MOGAD is typically bilateral, compared to MS which is typically unilateral.

answer_text: Sagittal STIR MR of cervical spine shows extensive longitudinal transverse myelitis from C4-C7. There are additional signal abnormality at C2 in the pons. question_text: What requirements must be met before a diagnosis of ADEM myelitis can be considered?
answer_text: There must be encephalopathy with MR brain findings consistent with ADEM, and MR spine findings consistent with a transverse myelitis, there cannot be any relapsing disease, or antibodies to suggest NMOSD or MOGAD.

question_text:
What is the clinical difference between Guillain–Barré syndrome and chronic
inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP)? What are the MR imaging differences?
answer_text: Guillain–Barré syndrome typically resolves or improves within 4 weeks. If the symptoms persist for longer than 8 weeks or there are multiple recurrences then the disease is CIDP. On MR GBS will demonstrate enhancement of the spinal nerve roots with no abnormal thickening. Compared to CIDP which demonstrates enhancement and nerve root thickening. There is no abnormal spinal cord signal in either of these entities.

question_text: This patient had progressive bilateral lower extremity weakness that has persisted for over 8 weeks. What does this MR indicate?
answer_text:
Sagittal T2WI MR reveals enlargement and abnormal T2 hyperintensity of
the exiting lumbosacral nerves. Diffuse nerve root hypertrophy and enhancement is the typical features of chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP).

question_text: What is chronic recurrent multifocal osteomyelitis (CRMO)?
answer_text: Chronic recurrent multifocal osteomyelitis (CRMO) is an autoinflammatory disorder of bone with multifocal painful non-pyogenic bone lesions typically seen in children or adolescents. MRI typically shows multifocal bone marrow edema, often involving the metaphysis of long bones, clavicles, spine, pelvis, frequently bilateral or symmetric.

question_text: What is Grisel syndrome? What imaging modality and procedures is best to diagnose this condition?
answer_text: Grisel syndrome is a rare cause of torticollis that involves subluxation of atlanto-axial joint due to inflammation of atlanto-axial ligaments from an infectious process in the head and neck, usually a retropharyngeal abscess. This is typically seen in children less than 18 years old. CT with the initial scan in a neutral position followed by maximum contralateral head turn looking for abnormal lateral placement of C1 on C2. MR can also be helpful in evaluating the extent of infection but the CT is best for evaluating the degree of subluxation.

question_text: What gender and age group is more likely to develop IgG4 related disease?
answer_text: IgG-4 related disease more commonly affects men more than women, and has a peak onset in patients in their 60s.

question_text: If a child with bilateral diffuse white matter changes involving the brain is diagnosed with presumed ADEM has recurrent symptoms 2 months later? is this considered a relapse? does this raise concern for MS?
answer_text: In cases of ADEM if symptoms return within 3 months, then it is considered to be part of the the same event and not a true relapse. However, this is still an uncommon event and may indicate an eventual evaluation of possible MOGAD or MS.

question_text: What MS drug has the highest risk of JC virus related progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML)?
answer_text: Natalizumab

question_text: What intracranial vessel supplies the lateral and posterior medulla?
answer_text: PICA - Posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

question_text: What intracranial vessel supplies the lateral and posterior pons?

question_text: What clinical syndrome is associated lateral medullary infarcts often supplied by a branch of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery.
answer_text: Lateral medullary syndrome, also called Wallenberg syndrome, which is characterized by loss of pain and temperature sensation of the ipsilateral face (from the descending trigeminothalamic tract) and contralateral body (from the lateral spinothalamic tract).

question_text: What region of the brain is involved in Wallenberg syndrome?
answer_text: The lateral medulla which is supplied by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

question_text: If a patient has stroke symptoms characterized by loss of pain and temperature sensation of the face and contralateral body, where should you look for an infarct?
answer_text: These neurologic deficits are consistent with Wallenberg syndrome, also called lateral medullary syndrome, and involve the lateral medulla which is supplied by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

question_text: What vessel is likely the cause of this infarct?
answer_text: The left posterior inferior cerebellar artery which supplies the lateral medulla. An infarct in the lateral medulla causes symptoms of loss of pain and temperature sensation of the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, ataxia, vertigo, and nystagmus, characterized as Wallenberg syndrome, also called lateral medullary syndrome.

question_text: Do collimators reduce low energy photos?
answer_text: No, collimators reduce scatter radiation which can inevitably increase exposure time by decreasing incident photons on the detector. Filters can reduce low energy photons.

question_text: In fibromuscular dysplasia, what part of the vessel is most commonly involved?
answer_text: In about 90% of cases of fibromuscular dysplasia the media of the arterial wall is involved.

question_text: In cases of fibromuscular dysplasia what section of the carotid artery is most commonly involved?
answer_text: The internal carotid artery cervical segment is most commonly affected in fibromuscular dysplasia. Interestingly, the proximal 2 cm from the carotid bulb is usually spared because of architectural differences in this part of the vessel's wall.

question_text: Are males or females more likely to have spinal epidural lipomatosis?

question_text: What systemic disease and what medications can be associated with spinal epidural lipomatosis?

Steroid use
Cushing syndrome
Hypothyroidism
Obesity

question_text: How is spinal epidural lipomatosis treated in patients with neurologic symptoms?
answer_text: Surgical decompression.

question_text: Is widening of the diploid space more common in Paget disease or cranial fibrous dysplasia?
answer_text: This is widening of the diploic space, which refers to expansion of the cancellous (spongy) bone between the inner and outer tables of the skull. Widening of the diploic space is associated with Paget disease, fibrous dysplasia, and other metabolic and hemolytic abnormalities. Diploic space widening is most pronounced in Paget disease.

question_text: Differentiating features between Paget disease and cranial fibrous dysplasia?
answer_text: Cranial fibrous dysplasia typically affects younger patients while, paget disease is in older patients. Fibrous dysplasia can involve the facial bones, including the sinuses while Paget disease typically spares the facial bones. Fibrous dysplasia predominantly affects the outer table compared to the Paget disease which involves both the outer and inner tables. In paget's disease the bone has a mixed lytic–sclerotic appearance while fibrous dysplasia appears more ground glass. Alkaline phosphatase is elevated in Paget's disease.

question_text: What is the diploid layer of the bone?
answer_text: The diploic layer is the layer of bone between the inner and outer table.

question_text: What types of metastatic disease can appear similar to Paget disease in the skull with the typical cotton wool, mixed sclerotic and lytic lesions?
answer_text: Metastatic prostate and breast cancers can appear similar to Paget disease in the skull.

question_text: A patient with paget disease can develop what issue with the kidney?
answer_text: Kidney stones

question_text: What pathogen is often the cause behind infectious osteomyelitis discitis?
answer_text: Staph aureus.

question_text: Is the incidence of a paraspinal abscess more or less likely in tuberculous spondylodiscitis or typical pyogenic spondylodiscitis.
answer_text: The incidence of a paraspinal abscess is high with tuberculosis compared to typical pyogenic infections.

question_text: Two most common locations of gangliogliomas in the brain?
answer_text: Gangliogliomas are typically located in the temporal lobes (85% of the time), and frontal lobe approximately 10% of the time.

question_text: What part of the mandible is at highest risk of avascular necrosis following a fracture?
answer_text: Fractures of the mandibular condyle, and specifically the mandibular neck are at highest risk of avascular necrosis.

question_text: What part of the mandible most commonly fractures?
answer_text: The body is most common location of a mandibular fracture, followed by the angle of the mandible and then the mandibular condyle.

question_text: Besides fractures, what other things can cause avascular necrosis of the mandible?
answer_text: Bisphosphonates and corticosteroids use, and sickle cell disease, can cause avascular necrosis of the mandible?

question_text: What is the concern of a mandibular fracture involving the alveolar process and teeth?
answer_text: A mandibular fracture involving the alveolar process and teeth is considered an open fracture due to communication with the oral cavity.

question_text: How does radiation intensity change with distance from the source?
answer_text: Radiation intensity decreases with the square of the distance from the source. This describes the inverse square law if the distance from the radiation source is doubled, the radiation intensity falls to one-quarter of the original intensity.

question_text: Most common location of an intracranial aneurysm?
answer_text: The anterior communicating arteries

question_text: Most common location of an intracranial posterior circulation aneurysm?
answer_text: Basilar artery tip aneurysm.

question_text: Cranial nerve anatomy. What separates the internal auditory canal into superior and inferior components?
answer_text: The crista falciformis (also called the horizontal crest).

question_text: Is spinal cord necrosis more commonly associated with neuromyelitis optica or multiple sclerosis.
answer_text: Spinal cord necrosis is more likely to be seen in neuromyelitis optica than MS.

question_text: What are the three major criteria for diagnosing neuromyelitis optica? What are the minor criteria?
answer_text: Optic neuritis, transverse myelitis with spinal cord lesion extending over three spinal segments, and absence of another known neurologic disease. All three of these must be present. Only one of the minor criteria must be met.  Positive CSF Aquaporin-4 Antibody, Linear periventricular white matter signal abnormalities, non-specific T2 signal in brainstem or hypothalamus, or a totally normal brain MRI.

question_text: Is neuromyelitis optica known to relapse? What about ADEM?
answer_text: Neuromyelitis often relapses and requires long-term immunosuppression. ADEM is monophasic and doesn't typically relapse. In-fact, if a presumed episode of ADEM does relapse, an alternative diagnosis is often investigated.

question_text: What is the best imaging study to find the location of an active CSF leak within the cranium?
answer_text: CT cisternography is performed by first obtaining a lumbar puncture, followed by intrathecal injection of a small volume of nonionic iodinated contrast. After allowing time and appropriate patient positioning for the contrast to circulate within the CSF, a thin-section CT of the skull base is obtained. The study is timed to identify extravasation of contrast outside the subarachnoid space, thereby localizing an active CSF leak.

question_text: What is the best imaging study to evaluate for a spinal CSF leak?
answer_text: CT myelogram

question_text: How are spinal CSF leaks often repaired?
answer_text: Epidural blood patch

question_text: What lab test can look for CSF fluid from nasal or ear drainage fluid to determine if is truly CSF?
answer_text: Beta-2 Transferrin

question_text: Does optic neuritis typically cause papilledema?
answer_text: No, optic neuritis can cause inflammation of optic disc and can resemble papilledema on fundoscopic exam, however MR does not typically show flattening of the optic disc in optic neuritis.

question_text: What is the abnormality?
answer_text: Papilledema, as indicated by flattening of the optic disc and bulging of the papilla into the globe.

question_text: Patient has sensory loss and weakness. What could this be?
answer_text: There is bilateral thickening of the lumbosacral spinal nerve roots. These findings can be seen in chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP), Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 3 (also called Dejerine-Sottas disease. Clinical history is helpful as Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease presents in infancy, while CIDP occurs in adults and can relapse. CIDP will often have mild enhancement of the nerve roots, while Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease does enhance.

question_text: Pre and post contrast of the lumbar spine. Immunocompromised patient with severe radicular pain. what could be included in the differential diagnosis?
answer_text: There is non-enlarged, left, greater than right spinal root enhancement of the cauda equina. Due to this patients immunocompromised status, CMV and Varicella zoster virus radiculitis are the most likely possibilities. If there is associated burning or vesicular rash in the region of pain this is more compatible with varicella zoster. Where rapid weakness is more associated with CMV radiculitis.

question_text: General differential diagnosis list of nerve root enlargement with enhancement.
answer_text:
4 main categories included in this differential inflammatory and autoimmune, neoplastic, infectious, and hereditary.
Inflammatory and autoimmune causes include Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP) - which is a common cause and represent a more chronic form of guillain barre syndrome last longer than 8 weeks, and enhancement can be variable and sometime absent in later stages. Neurosarcoid can cause enlargement and often nodular enhancement of the spinal nerve roots.  Leptomeningeal carcinomatosis, and lymphoma can also present with smooth or nodular enhancement of the spinal nerve roots. A nerve sheath tumors (including either schwannomas or neurofibromas) can have focal enlargement with avid enhancement. Infectious causes can be included, especially in immunocompromised patients and include tuberculosis, fungal like cryptococcus, CMV, and VZV. Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease would not be included in this differential list because although the spinal nerve roots are enlarged there is no enhancement with this disease.

question_text: This patients has been having progressive low extremity weakness for the past week. What is the most likely diagnosis?
answer_text: Ventral and dorsal nerve root enhancement without significant enlargement. With this patient's history of progressive lower extremity weakness a diagnosis of Guillain-Barre syndrome is most likely.

question_text: Regarding MR K-space how can truncation artifact, also known as Gibbs artifact occur? What are the primary and secondary methods that this artifact can be mitigated?
answer_text:
Truncation artifact occurs when k-space is incompletely sampled, particularly the peripheral high-spatial-frequency data due to a limited matrix size or reduced phase-encoding steps, resulting in oscillations near sharp tissue interfaces.
The primary method to mitigate this artifact is acquiring more k-space data, most effectively by increasing the matrix size, especially in the phase-encoding direction, or when partial Fourier is used, by increasing the fraction of phase-encoding k-space that is acquired.
Secondary methods act on already acquired data and include apodization and zero-filling interpolation.
Adopization users a filter or kernel, which reduces ringing artifact by smoothing edge transitions at the expense of mild spatial resolution loss.
Zero-filling interpolation smooths the image appearance without increasing true resolution. These secondary methods are less effective at mitigating the truncation artifact compared to increasing phase-encoding data acquisition.

question_text: What is apodization?
answer_text: Apodization reduces truncation artifact by applying a k-space filter kernel that tapers peripheral high-frequency data, decreasing ringing at the cost of spatial resolution.

Increasing bandwidth, which will also decrease the signal-to-noise ratio, making the the images less sensitive to artifact.
Shortening the echo time can help reduce metallic artifact.
Also orienting the frequency encoding direction in parallel to the long axis of the metallic device can help reduce metallic artifact. 
Increasing the field of view and decreasing the voxel size can help reduce metallic artifact.

question_text: What MR characteristics can help potentially differentiate a neurofibroma from a schwannoma?
answer_text:
The target sign is more common in neurofibromas, where there is a T2 hyperintense periphery and a T2 hypointense center.
However, this is not very specific and can also be seen in schwannomas sometimes.
Neurofibromas are less likely to be cystic compared to schwannomas.

This patient has neurofibromatosis type 1.
What is this imaging finding called?
answer_text:
There is posterior vertebral scalloping due to these neurofibromas causing widening of the dural sacs.
This is called dural ectasia.

question_text: Besides neurofibromatosis, what other disease commonly causes dural ectasia, particularly involving the lumbar spine?
answer_text: Marfan syndrome, due to connective-tissue weakness of the dura from fibrillin 1 mutations.

question_text: Where are spinal paragangliomas typically located?
answer_text: Cauda equina and the filum terminale.

question_text: Can spinal hemangioblastoma be intradural extramedullary?
answer_text:
Yes, spinal hemangioblastomas can be intradural and extramedullary, however this less common than the typical intramedullary hemangioblastoma.
When hemangioblastomas are extramedullary they are almost always associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease.

What is possible risk factor in developing an epidermoid cyst, especially at this spinal level.
answer_text: Lumbar punctures, particularly in pediatric patients, increases the risk of developing a spinal epidermoid cyst in the future, due to the unintended implantation of epithelial tissue into the thecal sac.

question_text: What is a orthotopic os odontoideum compared to a dystopic os odontoideum?
answer_text:
A dystopic os odontoideum is when the ossicle is fused to the basion.
An orthotopic os odontoideum is diagnosed when the ossicle moves with the anterior arch of C1.
